newsitem.title: USA: Calif. electric plan may not phase-in open access.
newsitem.headline: Calif. electric plan may not phase-in open access.

text.p: California's plan to allow competition in the state's electricity industry may begin for all customers next January, rather than phasing-in over several years, according the California Public Utilities Commission (CPUC).
But "practical and commercial" constraints could delay full implemenation to mid-1998, said David Gamson, advisor to commissioner Josiah Neeper.
Neeper and Jessie Knight, the commissioners assigned to electricity restructuring, are expected to submit a draft proposal early next month, with a vote by the full commission expected in late March.
State legislation passed last year called for all California customers to be able to choose their electricity supplier no later than Jan 1, 2002.
But Neeper and Knight have said that, barring any technical or operational constraints, there should be no limits on open access as of next January.

Gamson noted that the state's three major utilities, Edison International, PG&E Corp and Enova Corp, in January agreed that there are no technical barriers to achieving open access for all customers at once.
The draft proposal is expected, however, to include "contingency" plans which would be triggered if practical problems arise.
These plans would allow full open access to be delayed by six months, although some percentage of customers would begin open access next January as the state legislation requires, Gamson said.
